text.*:
This article is about the current situation of health in Ukraine.

Contents

  • 1 Health status
    • 1.1 Vaccinations
    • 1.2 High blood pressure and obesity
    • 1.3 Smoking
    • 1.4 Disability
    • 1.5 HIV/AIDS
    • 1.6 Mental health
  • 2 Demographic decline
  • 3 See also
  • 4 Notes
  • 5 References
  • 6 External links

Health status[edit]

An ambulance in Kiev.

Vaccinations[edit]

The crumbling poorly financed healthcare system and rumours that children have fallen ill or even died after being immunised have led to a very poor vaccination rate.[1][2][3] In August 2016, 30% of children in Ukraine were fully immunized against measles, 10%, against hepatitis B, and 3% of against diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus.[4] At the time Ukraine had the lowest routine immunization rate in the world.[5]

High blood pressure and obesity[edit]

Further information: Obesity in Ukraine

According to a study, entitled "Main reasons for the high death rate in Ukraine" conducted by the World Bank and released in December 2010 every third Ukrainian aged 18–65, including every fifth aged 18–25, had a high blood pressure. Almost 29% of the respondents suffered overweight, and 20% suffered from obesity.[6]

Smoking[edit]

According to the above-mentioned 2010 World Bank study 36% (28.6% is the average in Europe) of Ukrainians smoke tobacco, including 31% of those who smoke every day. Men with primary education and women with higher education are inclined to smoking. Some 80% of daily smokers are usually men. The average age that daily smokers start the habit is decreasing, and at present is 16 years. In the younger age group there are four times as many smokers as in the older age group. The smallest percentage of smokers is to be found in the west of the country (24.6%), while the largest is in the east (34%).[7]

Disability[edit]

Further information: Disability in Ukraine

2.7 million people in Ukraine (6%[8]) were reported as having a disability in 2014.[9] This number did not include the (reportedly) 1.5% of people with temporary disabilities.[9] In 2014, 35% of people aged 60–70 had some age-related disability. For people aged over 80 years, this number grew to 50%.[9]

Ukraine is notoriously "disability unfriendly".[9][10] For example in the capital Kiev only 4% of infrastructure is considered to be "disability friendly".[9]

HIV/AIDS[edit]

Main article: HIV/AIDS in Ukraine

Ukraine has one of the fastest growing HIV/AIDS epidemics in the world. About 1.63 percent of Ukrainian adults, or about 756,300 citizens, were estimated to be living with HIV/AIDS in 2007, up from 1.46 percent of the population in 2005, or 685,600 citizens, according to UNAIDS. The statistics only reflect official cases, while those infected is likely higher according to UNAIDS.[11] The number of HIV/AIDS cases in Ukraine reduced by 200 or 3.9% to 4,900 in the period of January–November 2008, compared with the corresponding period of last year. Ukraine has one of the highest rates of increase of HIV/AIDS cases in Eastern Europe.[12]

Mental health[edit]

Due to its mainly macho, patriarchal culture there is great resistance to psychotherapy in Ukraine.[13] Weak mechanisms for licensing effective counsellors aggravates this resistance.[13] A shame fostered by the years Ukraine was part of the Soviet Union[nb 1] compounds the problem.[13] Soviet authorities rendering psychiatry a tool for punishment (by imprisoning political dissidents in asylums) demonised mental health issues further.[13]

Demographic decline[edit]

Further information: Demographics of Ukraine

Ukraine is considered to be in a demographic crisis due to its high death rate and a low birth rate. The current Ukrainian birth rate is 11 births/1,000 population, and the death rate is 16.3 deaths/1,000 population. A factor contributing to the relatively high death is a high mortality rate among working-age males from preventable causes such as alcohol poisoning and smoking.[15]

In 2008, the country's population was one of the fastest declining in the world at -5% growth.[16][17] The UN warned that Ukraine's population could fall by as much as 10 million by 2050 if trends did not improve.[18]

See also[edit]

  • Healthcare in Ukraine

Notes[edit]

  1. ^ As the Ukrainian SSR Ukraine was part of the Soviet Union since 1920 until Ukraine declared its independence from the Soviet Union on 24 August 1991.[14]
